name: Law of Conservation
description: The Federation is crippled overnight when transporters universally stop functioning. Is it an act of sabotage, or some new law of physics? Work with the brightest minds in the universe to find the answer!
rules:
-- Unique Supply Missions are available during the event. Open the Event to access them.
-- Using any version of Erickson, Altan Soong, Rand or crew with the Innovator trait will provide a bonus to Supply Missions.
-- Every Supply Mission you complete earns you Event Victory Points. Collect Event Victory Points to unlock Threshold Rewards!
-- Community Rewards are only available during Phase 1. Collect Event Victory Points to unlock these rewards before the phase change!
-- In this event, Squadrons may also compete to advance up the Squadron leaderboards. Join a Squadron to get more rewards!
bonus_text: Crew Bonus: Erickson, Altan Soong, Rand or Innovators
rewards_teaser: Reach Rank 1 by gaining Victory Points from Event Supply Missions!

featured_crew.name: Altan
featured_crew.flavor: Working with Sutra, Soong built a beacon to contact the protectors of synthetic life for the creations he considered his children.

next_threshold_rewards.name: Chronitons
next_threshold_rewards.flavor: Chronitons allow your crew to take action in these chaotic times. Use Chronitons to replay parts of past missions via the Timeline.

screens.text: "I'm sure you received the emergency briefing stating all transporters should be deactivated until further notice. Well, it's not just Starfleet. Across the entire Federation, transporters are no longer working properly."

"When I designed the transporter, time was an arrow. Now it's... none of us really know what it is, anymore. But there are now forces in play that I could never have accounted for. What if all these years, all those transports, we've been building towards this crisis?"

"I admire your willingness to find fault in your own design, but let's not get ahead of ourselves. We need to understand whether this problem is limited to the Federation's transporters, or common to all of them, everywhere, across faction lines."
"It's confirmed. It doesn't matter who owns them, who operates them, or how they were designed: all transporters in the universe no longer function properly. So many lives lost...."
"We'll find a solution. Until then, we can go back to old methods. We could all use more exercise, right?"

responses.text: "Doctor Soong is right. There are likely temporal forces at work here."
"You're being alarmist. Our ancestors did fine without transporters."

screens.text: "You're making light of a serious problem. Without transporters, the Federation is crippled. Whole supply chains are broken. Medical emergencies can't get to where they need to go. We need to fix this now, and I think Emory was on to something."
"Define 'fine.' Because fine centuries ago meant many more lives lost, directly and indirectly, for lack of speedy transport. Emory wanted more than fine, and so do I."
"Emory, you mentioned something about critical mass, that every time we transport, we were building towards a problem. I agree with you, but not since your invention--since this crisis."
"What if every time we've transported someone not of this timeline, we've transported them in every timeline? Creating infinite copies, little black holes of transportees here and there and--"
"That's a fine theory. But I'm more interested in solutions. Let's get to finding one."
